div.p: 1. IV:15. Tuesday— Fahrenheit 28.

I executed with John J. Carr, the lease of my homestead farm for five years from the first of April next; but he is to quit the farm house, and is now building a house for him self, at the corner of the road leading to the Meeting House— My Son Charles, with his wife, his three children, and the Nursery maid Catherineleft us this morning and returned to Boston— They have been residing with us from the first of August, and have made our house so lively and pleasant that it seems as scarcely a week since they came— The summer has flown away as by enchantment; not I hope without my deep gratitude— Morning visit to take leave, from Mr Peter Whitney— The Weather continues clear and dry, but cold as December, and I find myself constantly baffled with my plantations— Mrs Adams went this afternoon to fish for smelts, and took the two children with her, but had no success. The coloured man servant who came with us from Washington, Graymes has been several times very ill, and confined to his bed within the last fortnight; he was taken this Evening suddenly with so violent a pain in the foot, that we sent for Dr Woodward, who came at nearly ten O’Clock— He thinks the disease inflammatory rhumatism— Mr Beale was here this Evening. His Son and his daughter Ann are both quite ill— A young man by the name of Ridout came and asked my permission to take away the Stumps from my Pine Hill woodland, for fuel— I at first refused him the permission; but he said that when the house was on fire in 1821. he and his father had both assisted to extinguish it, and had stood a long time in the water at the pond,—that he had now a wife and children to support and had been afflicted with sickness in his family— That the price of wood was distressingly high and he knew not how to get it, I told him he might take the Stumps on condition that he should take nothing else, which he faithfully promised. He promised also to notify Mr Spear when he should take the Stumps away and of the quantity that he takes— Mr Josiah Adams junr was here too this evening; about a settlement of his account for building the House at Mount Wollaston; but I was not ready for him— I paid however Whiting the Mason’s bill for work done at this house.
2 IV:15. Wednesday.

Fahrenheit 30— William Spear brought me this morning the plan drawn by Mr Humphrey of the woodlot on Pinehill sold some days since by Peter Turner and Samuel Copland, and which Turner offered me for 500 dollars— They sold first the wood standing on the lot, and then the lot itself, which was boughten by Copland for 26. dollars and a half an Acre— Copland offers it now to me at that price, and I told Spear I would take it, if Copland would take my note, payable the first of next May, without interest in payment— Harvey Field was here yesterday and paid me 118 dollars 75 Cents, for one fourth part of the contract for the standing wood on the Verchild and Atherton Pasture— He said that Mr Gideon Thayer of Braintree wished for permission to split a rock there, experimentally— I told him that I should refer Mr Thayer and all other persons proposing to split rocks upon my lands to my Son, for all agreements on that subject.— Field told me that he and Thomas Adams junr. had made each 900 dollars, by their speculation in Bracketts Estate along the line of the Canal, which they have laid out in House-lots, and lots for wharfage— I went to the Bank, and made there a
a deposit, and an exchange of large for small bills.— I next went in to Mr Bracketts, and he witnessed the execution, and took the acknowledgment of the Assignment of my pew N. 61. in the Stone Temple to my Son Charles. Mr Brackett had a Barometer and Thermometer hanging in his parlour— He told me the Barometer had fallen nearly a quarter of an inch since Sunrise, which portended a considerable change of the weather— It was already clouding up, after about ten days of a crystal clear sky and nightly severe frosts.— Returning home, I came round, by the quarries at which John Hardwick’s men, and Colburn and Dutton were at work. I gathered a few farm walnuts; none of which however have ripened; and a few red wedge, and Russet Apples, yet hanging on the trees, and upon which I intend to make the experiment of planting from the seed— Both crabs; but sound fruit, almost entirely free from worms; and stocked with very good looking seeds— After dinner I planted in plat 1. of the Seminary new row, several red wedge Apple and farm wilding Pear seeds; wild plum Stones and farm walnuts— The storm came on in the Evening—Wind—rain and Sleet.— I packed up with John Wilson, a trunk full of old documents to be sent to Washington.
3. IV. Thursday.

Storm all night and the whole of this day with alternation of Sleet, rain and Snow. Towards evening it held up without clearing up— I was confined all day to the house; and yet idled away my time, chiefly in directing copies of the Eulogy on James Madison to sundry persons, and correcting the errata— I received a Letter from S. S. Southworth expressing in terms of extravagant applause for his opinion of the Eulogy and requesting a copy of it— Quite probably he may publish a bitter and sneering critical review of it— Jefferson paid Callender for reviling and slandering my father, and called it charity— Webster paid Southworth, or at least promised to pay him for reviling and slandering me, and may call it Charity, if he has paid— Southworth is one of the best representatives of the class of political writers for hire in this Country. He has been one of the most virulent lampooners upon me of the whole tribe, and has written me many Letters full of kindness and veneration— From his Letter now, I conclude that he is going to Washington to correspond with the Publishers of Newspapers throughout the United States, and wishes me again to understand that he is a disinterested man in the market— Webster probably cannot afford to pay for his lucubrations now.
4. IV:30. Friday

William Spear came this morning, and told me that Copland was willing to take my note payable the first of May next for the 6 acres of naked woodland on Pine Hill, but insisted that it should be upon interest, to which I consented— My Son Charles came out from Boston, dined with us, and returned immediately after dinner— Our departure for Washington is now so near at hand that it unsettles all my ordinary occupations, suspends my correspondence and the regular record of my Diary; and there are circumstances which are peculiarly disturbing to me at this time— Mrs Adams had at first fixed upon this day for our departure, which I would gladly have postponed three weeks longer— The weather for the last fortnight has been so continuously cold and wintery, that it has allowed me no plea for protracting the Journey, and our household Servant man, Graymes disabled by inflammatory rhumatism, has been much more burdensome than helpful to us.— Our departure is now projected for next Monday— The morning was so frosty that after making my fire, I could not Journalize, and I read a chapter of Benjamin Constant’s third Volume on Religion. I was the whole Morning, planting, brown sugar Pear Cores—Sundry Apple seeds, and
wild plums, and walnuts on the plats surrounding eight young seedling fruit-trees, transplanted from my garden and Nursery into the Seminary— In the last three years I have laid out four of those rows; each of 8 transplanted seedling fruit trees— In the plats round the trees I sow seeds and plant nuts and stones with the ultimate view of having on each plat a transplanted Seedling, and a tree from the seed, growing at the same time— I have done this heretofore without regularity, and with partial success— I now undertake it more extensively.— After dinner I sowed several rows of farm apple seeds in the Garden box N. 2.— In the Evening I received 100 copies of the Eulogy on James Madison; 50 of them with strips of brown cartridge paper over them, which Mary directed to sundry persons of my acquaintance, which I franked to be forwarded by the Mail. I received also a Letter from Daniel Webster, with the Manuscript Dissertations on the Congress of Nations. Josiah Adams junr was here this Evening, but I was not ready for a Settlement with him—
5. IV:15 Saturday.

Mrs. Adams and Mary went into Boston, with Elizabeth C Adams and left me to dine with the children alone— William Spear, and Samuel Copland junr were here. Copland gave me, executed, and acknowledged, his Deed of the lot of 6. Acres of woodland on Pine Hill, with Peter Turner’s Quit claim deed to him, andCapen’s Deed to them as Tenants in Common— Neither of which was recorded. I sent them all to Boston, to my Son, to have them recorded with the other Deed from Peter Turner, at Dedham—and with them I sent all my Deeds of real Estate and other property here in Massachusetts and at Philadelphia, to be kept by my Son, till my return home next Spring— Intending to take with me the Deeds and vouchers of my property at Washington— I gave Copland, my Note upon interest, payable the first of next May— Spear told me that he had seen and spoken to Benjamin Bass who refused to sign the Assignment of the Policy; but said he would pay his note soon, and when pressed by Spear to say when, still said soon, and finally, before the year should come round— Josiah Adams junr. was again here, and I paid him 100 dollars, part on account of his own Bill, and the remainder, for Brigham’s Bill for glass— Adams is to wait for the settlement of the rest of his account for the new House at Mount Wollaston, and for his new Entry and passage way at the homestead, till December or January, when Charles is to pay him— Afternoon visit to take leave, from Mr Lunt, and Mr and Mrs John Angier from Medford were here— She is to spend two days with her mother, but he was obliged to return this Evening to Medford. This afternoon my Grand daughters Mary Louisa and Georgiana Frances planted each in her plat in the Seminary sundry Apple and Pear Seeds, Plums, Peach Stones and Walnuts, and I trust some one or more of them will come up in each plat— I would have each of them interested in the growth of a tree from a seed sown by herself— Mary-Louisa is already much interested in her vine, which survived the last Winter, and has flourished well this Season; but it cannot live long, and there should be something more hardy to take its place— I planted—Apple and Pear seeds, round 8. of the young transplanted fruit trees in the Seminary, and marked them all upon Stakes— Planted also 4 rows of Pear seeds in garden box 3. but forgot the Stakes— They were the farm wilding, farm button, and two of the garden Endicott—a thorough winter Pear. I have not been able to carry through my whole plan, but I mark especially the two wilding Pears, the Garden Endicott, the farm red wedge and farm Russet Apples for seed.
6. IV:15. Sunday.— Fahrenheit 30

Mr White of Dedham, preached in the morning from 1. Timothy 6. and I believe 16. and in the afternoon from Hebrews 2.1. “Therefore we ought to give the more earnest heed to the things which we have heard, lest at any time we should let them slip.”— My mind was so unsettled by the near approach of my departure, and my attention so much absorbed, by the many things always at such times claiming attention, that the text and the discourse were lost upon me—and I could give so little heed to the things which I heard, that I did let them all slip. and I was but little more heedful of the 8th. Sermon of the 9th. Volume of Saurin, which I read and which was upon the transformation of the Christian, or upon regeneration,—He treats the subject in a manner rather different from that of ordinary Calvinism, and more rational— Mr White dined with us, and is a man of modest demeanour and pleasant manners— After the evening service, Mr E. Price Greenleaf came into my library, and looked over my books to select those which he wishes to borrow, and proposes in the course of the winter to read— He took out Humboldt’s travels, and some others which I promised to send him— He has promised also to take for the winter the Pot containing the brown bury pear Seedling, to see if he can keep it alive— Mr Degrand came out from Boston, and spent the Evening with me— The Ladies with the children were at Mrs T. B. Adams’s— Degrand’s chief anxiety is for the money market— We have again concluded to postpone our departure another day.
7. IV. Monday— Fahrenheit 29.

I think for the last fortnight there has been scarcely one morning without a frost— The trees are all strip’d of their leaves, and vegetation is absolutely dead— My Son Charles came out from Boston and dined with us, and returned home before Evening. We were engaged almost the whole day in settling Bills, and packing trunks, and I barely found time to plant a row of whole Apples from the Summerhouse cellar to the road, and another fronting the Nursery fence. I planted also Apple and Pear-seeds in the Pot N. 11. and had all the Pots removed into the cellar. I reserved some of the Farm red wedge, and russet Apples and Endicott Pears and wild Plums, to be kept till after my return here in the spring, with the intention of planting some of their seeds then. But I am again obliged to leave all my plantations in a confused state, and my experiments in most equivocal embryo— Mr James Herring was here— He is the compiler of a Work called the American Portrait Gallery containing engraved Portraits of sundry distinguished persons of this Country; all Post-revolutionary characters—with the Portraits are published biographical notices of the persons. Three Volumes of the work are published— Mr Herring has made repeated applications to me for the use of the Portraits of my father and mother, of my wife and of myself— I have offered him the use of the Portraits, painted by Copley, Stuart, and Leslie, but I believe none of them have yet been engraved— He has intreated me to furnish him Memoirs of my Mother, my wife, and of my father, and proposed that Mr William L. Stone of New-York should prepare the Memoir of me; to which I readily assented— Mr Herrings Applications to me have been frequent, but as yet little has been effected, and I strongly apprehend that nothing will be done, except what I shall do, or cause to be done myself— About a Month since I received a Letter from Mr Herring, dated at Plymouth, where he said he was copying
the large Picture, by Henry Sargent of the landing of the Pilgrims; and he then informed me that in about three weeks from that time he would come on here, and proposed to pass a Night at Quincy— He now informed me that a few days after writing that Letter, he had been obliged by the sudden illness and death of his mother at New-York to leave Plymouth, and had reached New-York, only to attend the funeral of his mother— He said they must finish the Gallery of Portraits with the fourth Volume, three being already completed, and for the Memoir of my mother he must depend entirely upon me— That Mr Stone was willing to write the memoir of me, but had said that he did not know whether I should now be willing that he should— I told him I could have no possible objection— I had lately differed from Mr Stone, upon some points of Politics, but was willing he should say of me just what he thought right— He said Mr Durand was now engraving his own portrait of me; that he himself was to copy Copley’s full length portrait of my father, and Cheney was to copy Stuart’s portrait of my mother, and one of those of my wife, by Leslie or Stuart. I told him she would prefer to have that of Leslie engraved, rather than that of Stuart.— I was so much engaged in preparations for departure, that my conference with Mr Herring was necessarily abridged— Mr Beale was here in the Evening but I did not see him. I sent to Mr E. Price Greenleaf the seedling Pear and the books which he selected yesterday.
8. IV. Tuesday.— From Quincy, through Boston and Providence to Long-Island Sound—

At half past nine this morning Gillet came with his stage and he took us to Boston— My wife, My Son John’s widow, Mary, with her two daughters, Mary Louisa, and Georgiana Frances, my niece Elizabeth C. Adams, Mrs Wilson, and Mrs Giusta who has been spending the Summer with us, and our Mulatto servant man Graymes—Marythe Cookmaid, and Sarah Frickey the House-maid went with us to Boston, and there left us— John Wilson with the Horses went last Evening to Walpole to meet us this day at the Steamboat at Providence— We came to the Rail-way Cars at Boston, at half past ten, and found there Mr James H. Foster, waiting to take leave of us— My Son Charles soon came with his boy John Quincy— I met also at the depot Dr Kirkland, and Mr Henry Sargent, who were there to take leave of departing friends— At 11. O’Clock the cars started, and just before half past one, landed us on the wharf at Providence.— The morning was lowering, and before we left Quincy there was a light shower of Rain: but soon after we started from Boston, the sky cleared up cool, but with a light breeze— The transition from Boston to Providence was so rapid, that there was time for observing nothing except the ground spotted with Snow from Roxbury to Attleborough— We had Cars full of fellow passengers, but among them no acquaintance— We found Wilson with the Horses on the wharf— But the tide was out, and the Steamer lay, with her deck so far below the level of wharf, that the Horses could not be led into the boat— I was obliged to leave Wilson with them there—to take the boat of tomorrow, and to follow us on to Washington as expeditiously as he can— I gave him 25 dollars in addition to the ten I had given him yesterday, and told him to make his way as well as he could— We embarked in the Steamer Narragansett Captain Coleman, a new and very swift boat, but long, sharp, and too moveable in the Water— Full of passengers; but none of our acquaintance— Mr Tillinghast of the Rhode-Island Legislature, landed at Newport, where we were not detained more than five minutes— As the Sun was setting we passed round Point Judith, cleaving the waters with a motion of at least twelve miles an hour, and with a Sea so smooth that the surge usually so swelling at that place was scarcely perceptible The weather continued equally fair through the Evening, and between ten
and eleven O’Clock, I turned in to my birth, having already passed the New London light, and entered Long-Island Sound—
9. V:30. Wednesday— New-York— Amboy— Philadelphia.

After a quiet Night, though nearly sleepless, rising at half past five, I found the boat in the East river, and at a quarter past six, we landed at the wharf below Chambers Street in the North river; whence we walked to the wharf adjoining the North end of the Battery, whence the Steam-boats for Amboy depart— The six O’Clock boat had been gone about half an hour, and we were obliged to wait for the Swan which was to depart at ten O’Clock— We breakfasted at the Philadelphia House a Tavern at the corner adjoining the Battery. I made up a packet of the Dissertations upon a Congress of Nations; directed it to Chancellor Kent, and sent it to the Post-Office— I then strolled about the city for about an hour—there was very little apparent agitation, although it was the third and last day of an election for Governor, Senators and House of Assembly; for four members of the House of Representatives of the United States and for forty two Electors of President and Vice President of the United States— There was not the slightest appearance of riot or disorder.— Twenty two thousand votes had been taken in the two preceding days, and about twelve thousand were to be taken this day— I returned in time for the departure of the Steamboat the Swan, at ten O’Clock. Met several persons of transient acquaintance, among whom, Mr Smith, heretofore Minister of the second Presbyterian Church at Washington, Mr Thomas Coolidge of Boston, and an Officer of the army whose name I could not ascertain, but who told me that he was with me, on the Cars of this same railway, this day three years ago, when we met with that Melancholy accident by which two men were killed and several others men women and children were maimed and crippled— This Officer then was accompanying the wife, child and Sister in Law of Lieutt. Bartlett of the Engineer Corps, all of whom suffered very severely by the disaster— We were this day more favoured; and after a smooth passage of three hours in the boat to Amboy; thence one of two hours in the cars to Bordentown, and then another of three hours in the Steamboat Trenton we landed at 6. O’Clock in the Evening at the Chesnut Street wharf— We walked to Congress Hall, corner of Chesnut and third Streets, and there found lodgings for the Night.— The house is now kept by a man named Sturdivant— I went and called upon Mr Nicholas Biddle, and spent an hour with him and his Lady— Then returned to our lodgings to which he accompanied me, and paid a short visit to Mrs Adams— Mary was overfatigued by the rapidity of our two days journey, and went to bed much indisposed— The whigs as they call themselves are just recovering from the delusion of an imaginary victory at the elections. Mentis gratissimus error— While they have been shouting their triumph they have been losing the day.
10. V. Thursday— From Philadelphia through Baltimore to Washington.

The Boat from Philadelphia to New-York starts at six in the Morning— That for Baltimore at seven— I rose in time for the first and waited for the second— We walked to the wharf and took passage in the Ohio, Captain Jeffreys for Newcastle—arrived there at ten— Took the Railway Cars; fine new vehicles each holding about 120 passengers—at 11 we reached Frenchtown and embarked in the Steam boat Constitution Captain Pierce, in which at a quarter past 3 we landed at the wharf in Baltimore—we walked to Barnum’s American
Hotel, where I left the Ladies and family, and went to the Office of the Railway Cars for Washington, where I took Seats for Washington and waited till half past 4. when I walked leisurely to Barnum’s, where I expected to find my family; but they were all gone from the room where I had left them, and neither the Bar keeper nor any of the Servants knew what had become of them— I concluded that without waiting for me they had gone to the Railway Offices, by another Street than those through which I had passed— I returned to the railway Office; but they were not there. The Clock had struck five— The Cars were to depart at precisely a quarter after 5— Graymes was at the Office with all the baggage— I told him if I should not be back in time, before the Cars should start, to go on with them and upon arriving at Washington to have the baggage carefully taken to our house— I raced back again to Barnum’s Hotel, and there was told that my family had just gone, escorted by Mr M’Laughlin the bar keeper, and that when I had been at the house for them before they were still in the house, but had left the room where I had first left them and gone to a more private chamber where they had waited for me till notified that they were in danger of losing their passage in the Cars— I flew back and reached the Cars an instant before their departure, just in time to take my Seat. My family had got there not five minutes before and were already seated. I was in a steam-bath of perspiration, of exhausted breath, of half-flayed feet, and of pungent reflections on the policy of going to Barnum’s Hotel to wait an hour and a half for the starting of the Railway Cars.— They proceeded with moderate speed, and I had time gradually to grow cool in body and mind, with two loquacious fellow travellers, one named M’Cormick, a brother of the Clergyman whom I placed in the Department of State—the other an Englishman settled in this Country named Maynard, who told me that he came to this Country from England when I was Minister there; and that I had furnished him with a Passport, his wife being an American— The Cars landed us about half past eight in the Evening, at the foot of the Capitol Hill in Washington, where Michel Antoine Giusta was waiting to meet his wife. The family and Graymes with the baggage came in Hacks, Mary and Elizabeth accompanied by Major Macomb, who had been a fellow traveller with us from New-York. I walked home with Giusta who entertained me on the way with the adventures of his expedition of the last Summer to the Western Country—as we came by the public buildings the Treasury Clock struck nine, and immediately after I entered our house, with silent gratulations that this journey of 500 miles had been performed in three days without any untoward accident— Mrs Goods was in the House ready to receive us. Graymes who has been limping and hobbling along with us more a burden than a benefit immediately left us and went to Georgetown.
11. IV:15. Friday. Washington

The weather had been beautifully clear, with cold nights and warm days from the hour of our departure from Boston, till last Evening when it clouded up with a prospect of rain— It came on in the Night, and rained steadily almost the whole of this day. It confined me accordingly all the morning to the House— I was resuming my customary winter occupations preparatory to the meeting of Congress— A young man named Watson Gore, of Roxbury who had been a fellow Traveller with us from New-York
and to whom the children had taken, with much attachment came to see them— He had come to the city merely for curiosity, and said he should return in the Cars to Baltimore this Evening.— Dr Huntt also paid us a visit— I heard the children read again—Mary Louisa in the Apocrypha, and both of them in the new Testament— As the rain held up towards Evening, I walked to see Mrs Smith in her new house, where she is very comfortably situated— Mr Smith is absent on a visit to New-York— The excitement of the Presidential Election is here as we have found it all along on the road— The remarkable character of this election is that all the candidates are at most third rate men, whose pretensions rest neither upon high attainments, nor upon eminent services, but upon intrigue and political speculation. The Presidency has fallen into a joint stock company— Jackson came in upon the trumpet-tongue of military achievement— His Presidency has been the reign of subaltern knaves, fattening upon land jobs and money jobs, who have made him believe that it was a heroic conception of his own to destroy the Bank of the United States, and who under colour of this have got into their own hands the use of the public monies at a time when there is a surplus of forty Millions of Dollars in the Treasury— Two political Swindlers Amos Kendall, and Reuben M. Whitney, are the Empson and Dudley of our Solomon, and by playing upon his Vanity, and his thirst of petty revenge have got into their own hands the overflowing revenue of the Country; with the temporary and illegal use of which they are replenishing their own Coffers and making princely fortunes.— Jackson has wearied out the sordid subserviency of his Supporters, and Van Buren has had the address to persuade him that he is the only man who can preserve and perpetuate the principles of his administration,—And as his term of eight years has run through, and his gang are weary of his sway, he has set his heart upon bringing in Van Buren as his Successor, and has successfully exercise all his influence to promote that result. The opposition divided between three talented aspirants to the Presidency, neither of whom would yield subordination to either of the others, have been driven in mere desperation to set up men of straw in their places, and they have taken up Hugh Lawson White and William Henry Harrison as the Israelites set up a calf, and as the Egyptians worshipped oxen and monkies. White and Harrison are men of moderate capacity, but of varied public service, and of long experience in the affairs of the Nation— They are as competent for the Presidency at least as Jackson, and like him, if elected to his Station, would rule by the proxy of subalterns— By party management and political love potions, White and Harrison are now the golden calves of the People, and their dull saying are repeated for wit, and their grave inanity is passed off for wisdom.— This bolstering up of mediocrity would seem not suited to sustain much enthusiasm; but a practice, has crept in of betting largely upon the issue of elections, and that adds a spar of private personal and pecuniary interest to the impulse of patriotism— This is the exciting cause of all the ardour which we have met with throughout this Journey— Mrs Smith says that Van Buren is so generally odious here, that if the report of Harrison’s having carried the State of Pennsylvania had been confirmed, the city would have been illuminated— When I came home, I found here Mr Frye who spent part of the Evening with us.— He gave me in general terms an account of the state of my property here— The situation of the City is not quite so desperate as it was; but its prospects have not much improved.

12. IV:15. Saturday.— The day was fair, and the temperature of the atmosphere so mild that I had no occasion for fire in my chamber, and had none— Nor was there any made in our Bed chamber— The first thing to which I found it necessary to attend was to recruit my funds, for I had imprudently left home with a charge of nine persons and two horses, with less than 200 dollars for the expenses of a journey of 500 Miles. I came therefore under a perpetual uneasiness with the fear of finding my resources exhausted on the way, and of being obliged to borrow some paltry sum of fifty dollars to complete my journey. I finally got through, with the help of ten dollars of the Money of Elizabeth C Adams which she had in Bills of Boston Banks, and found some difficulty in passing away— In the Steamboats they take the Bills of all the solvent Banks, and took without hesitation those which she had given me to exchange— These and one of three half-Eagles, which I had reserved to keep as curiosities landed me here, and paid for the marketing of this Morning. I went to the Bank of the Metropolis, and drew a small balance which I had left in deposit there— My next visit was to the Franklin Insurance Company, where I found the Secretary Mr Abraham Bradley. The Directors have just declared a dividend of 8 per Cent on the Capital for a half year, retaining 4 per Cent for the reserved fund; but they passed a Resolution requiring a new endorser upon ten of my notes, and another to refuse payment of the dividend to any Stockholder who should refuse to renew his notes, with a new endorser— Mr Bradley had written me a Letter notifying me of these Resolutions, and that he was ready to pay me the Dividend upon my renewal of my Notes— There were twelve of these Notes including one for thirty shares which had belonged to my Son John and upon which I was the endorser— He was one of the endorsers on all the rest— I told Mr Bradley that I still doubted the legal right of the directors to require new Notes— But I was very unwilling to have a lawsuit with them; and as my Son John’s property was bound by his name on the twelve Notes, I would take them all up, and offer his widow’s name as endorser upon one note including the amount of them all. He said that would satisfy the requisition of the directors, and drew a note for 19540 dollars, being the amount of the twelve Notes to be taken up, leaving the name of the payee in blank, which I filled up with the name of Mary C. Adams, and she endorsed it— There are still two Notes signed by me, one endorsed by Phineas Bradley fordollars and one by Jesse B. Nicholls fordollars of which the Directors have not required the renewal: those endorsers being neither dead nor insolvent— I called also at the Office of the National Intelligencer, and directed that the daily paper should be sent to my house. It has during my absence, been sent to Mr Frye’s— I saw Mr Seaton, who gave me some Boston Papers all full of electioneering. Gales is at New-York— Thomas J. Frye was here this afternoon— He is now in the Senior Class at the Columbian College, the prospects of which he thinks are improving— I wrote to Chancellor Kent, concerning the Dissertations on the Congress of Nations.
13. IV:15 Sunday.

At the second Presbyterian Church; heard Mr Fowler, the young man lately settled there; his text was part of Hebrews 6.1. “Therefore leaving the principles of the doctrines of Christ, let us go on unto perfection”— The principles of the doctrines of Christ, are subjects of faith and of argument. The movement onward to perfection must be, by works— Surely the Presbyterian creed is undergoing a revolution— The young men, all preach good works—and mere faith is losing its ascendancy. Mr and Mrs Frye, with their Son Thomas and Mrs W. S. Smith dined with us; whereby, the afternoon service at Church escaped me.— Mrs Adams with the young Ladies and the children attended, the morning worship at St. John’s Church— The remainder of the day slipped away without improvement— I have no books here adapted to the exercise of the meditations suitable to the solemnity of the day;—and although I have arrears of diary, and of correspondence to redeem, a perverseness of involuntary empulse substitutes other and less useful pastimes, which wear away the hour; and accumulate arrears until it becomes impossible to retrieve them— A chasm ensues, and I have finally no resource, but to begin again— Mary was unwell this day with a cold, cough, and headache, which they call influenza.
14. IV:30. Monday

A cold steady rain with a heavy gale of wind commenced last Night, and continuing through the whole of this day confined me wholly to the house— I should have recovered arrears, but suffered this day to be added to them.— I wrote one short Letter to the Clerk of the Jefferson Literary Society, Franklin College, New Athens, Harrison County, Ohio; but Mary was now confined to her bed, with a catarrhal fever. Elizabeth was also drooping, and I was indebted to my wife, for the copy of my Letter.— This was for the present an effective check upon my correspondence, and my Diary fared not much better— It was not however wholly neglected— But having occasion to refer to a Letter written since March 1834. when I began the present volume of my Letters, I had some embarrasment to find it and perceived that it wanted an index, and almost the whole of it paging— I determined then to make an index to the volume, and began minuting down the names of the persons to whom the Letters were written, in the order as they stand in the book— I wished also to collect the documents relating to the boundary controversy between Ohio and Michigan, for the purpose of writing out the substance of my Speech made at the last Session of Congress upon that question, which I have been requested to do, by Mr. Lucius Lyon, one of the elected Senators from the State of Michigan.— I have been willing in the cause of Justice to undertake this arduous, and most thankless task.— But in searching for the documents I was obliged to rummage over an enormous mass of pamphlets, which engrossed five or six hours of time, and after all without entire success, We have been expecting with some anxiety the arrival of Wilson whom we left at Providence with the horses— I thought he might be here this day; but conclude that he has not ventured to travel with them in this Storm— Graymes came the morning after our arrival, and took his leave: he said he was not able to do the duty of the place, but when he should recover hoped I would give him a recommendatory certificate— Giusta has taken a small house in this neighbourhood, where he intends to pass the winter— He and his wife have been here every day since our arrival.
15. II:45 and IV:30. Tuesday

I rose first before three O’Clock, and finding how time went, returned to bed, and lay awake nearly two hours before rising for the day— There are two particulars affecting my Sleep, which I scarcely know whether to charge to the body or to the mind— One that after my first sleep on going to bed, I awake very irregularly at different hours; almost always without knowing the immediate cause of my waking, and scarcely ever being able even to guess how long I have slept or what hour before or after midnight it is— The other, that when once thus waked I scarcely ever can sleep again the same night, and if I am roused at one or two O’Clock in the morning, I return to bed, but get no more Sleep— This time is often, but not always lost to me— It is occupied sometimes with useful and sometimes with idle meditation; and sometimes, as this morning with mere vacuity of mind— The storm of yesterday cleared up with a heavy gale in the Night, and this morning there was a Northwest wind, and a sharp frost— I pursued the preparation of the Index to my volume of Letters, and minuted the names about half through the book— I called at the War Department with Thomas Vinson’s papers; but the acting Secretary Mr Benjamin Franklin Butler, was attending a Cabinet Meeting at the Presidents I went to the Franklin Insurance Office, took up the twelve notes which the directors had required should be exchanged, and gave the new one including the amount of them all, and endorsed by Mary C. Adams my Son John’s widow— Mr Bradley then gave me two checks for the dividends due on the shares; and I asked him for a new certificate of the 30 Shares which had stood in the name of my Son John— He observed that the former certificate must be delivered up, and I had not thought of taking it with me— I went to the Patent Office, and paid the bill which had been sent to me for fees of recording papers; and to the Office of the National Intelligencer, where Mr Seaton gave me some of the last Boston Papers— On returning home I had a visit from General Macomb, who has been attending a Court of Inquiry upon Scott and Gaines at Frederick— The Court have adjourned till next week.
16. IV:15 Wednesday.

Instead of retrieving the arrears of my Diary, or of my correspondence, I am making an Index of my Letter Book, and hunting up and assorting old pamphlets— This morning I finished the minute of the names and the paging of the Book— It now remains to arrange the names in alphabetical order— Mary still continues confined to her chamber with a cough and Elizabeth is now afflicted with the same complaint— John Wilson arrived at last with the Horses, but quite sick, and took to his bed with a cold, and stricture over his breast.— It is a difficult, dangerous and expensive operation to transport horses 500 miles by Steam boats and railways. Dr Huntt was here, and Giusta, whom I asked to purchase for me some articles of furniture at auction, but who thought they would not suit me. I called again at the War Office, and left Thomas Vinson’s statement with Mr Butler the Attorney General, and acting Secretary of War, since the appointment and departure of Lewis Cass as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to France. Mr Dickerson the Secretary of the Navy came in while I was there— He has been very much indisposed, and said he was not able to attend the Cabinet Meeting yesterday— There is perhaps some disease of the
temper, sympathetic with that of the body; and it is said that the President treats him very harshly. I called at the Franklin Insurance Office with the Certificate of 30 Shares of the Stock in the name of my Son John, and Mr Bradley made out a new one in my name, but Mr Grammer the President was not there to sign it—so I am to call for it again. Their reserved fund amounts now to more than 25000 dollars—and I urged Mr Bradley to propose to the Directors to declare an extra dividend of 20 per Cent, and at the same time to call for a second instalment of five dollars a share from the Stockholders— The dividend would thus pay the instalment The amount of Capital paid in, and the Stock of every Stockholder would be doubled, and the Directors might continue to reserve one third of the half yearly profits for a new reserved fund; additional to that required by the Charter— The payment of the instalment would also release the Stockholders from one fourth of the amount of their contingent notes. New Notes reduced to three fifths of the payable capital might be given, and the reserves in a few years might prepare a payment of a third instalment after which a pledge of the Stock might be taken instead of any indorser of the contingent notes for the two remaining instalments. Mr Bradley said the extra dividend and call for a second instalment had been proposed at the board of Directors; but it had been suggested that it might not be consistent with the eighth Section of the Charter— I read the act, and found there was nothing in the eighth or any other Section, which my proposal would contravene— He said he would mention it to the President and Directors— I went to the Capitol and visited the Library, and the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives— I found some women at work in the house, laying the Carpets in preparation for the commencement of the Session. I applied for Copies of the Documents of the last Session of the Acts of Congress and of the Journals of both Houses.— At the Office of the National Intelligencer I saw both the Editors, Gales and Seaton, and took home with me some of the Boston Newspapers.
17. V. Thursday.

Giusta was here this morning and was going to Alexandria, where he expected to find the Articles of Table furniture which we want I had morning visits from Mr Nathaniel Amory, and from Mr Hawley the Minister— Mr Amory, who for some time past has resided at Newport, Rhode Island, proposes to pass the Winter in this City where he says he has some business. In the making up of the Index to my Letter Book, and the assortment of pamphlets I have consumed so much time, that this day I began to feel the necessity of beginning to redeem the arrears of my Diary— I kept house therefore till after dinner and then walked to Mr Frye’s— He was not at home, but I saw Mrs Frye— Returning home at the dusk of evening I passed by the house of the late Dr Joseph Lovell, Surgeon General of the Army. I saw a number of People collected in front of the door, and Dyer the Auctioneer was standing on the Steps, and bidding off the house— When I went from this City last July, Doctor Lovell and his wife were in the prime of life with a family of ten children, and apparently in as sound health as any two persons in the Country— Since then his wife and he have successively died of fevers—the children are left orphans under the guardianship of a relation of Mrs Lovell’s, and their house which he had built about ten years since for a permanent abode, passes under the hammer—what is human life?— So teach us to number our days, that we may apply our
hearts unto wisdom— I received yesterday a Letter from my Son Charles, dated the 12th. and informing me that he had that day received a notification directed to me, and signed by John R. Livingston jr. as Notary Public of the Manhattan Company—stating that on the day of its date the 9th. of this Month, Wolcott Chaunceys acceptance of my draft for 3000 dollars payable at the Manhattan Company’s Office, had been protested for nonpayment, and that the holders would look to me for payment— I immediately wrote to Mr. Livingston that I had never made any draft for money payable at the Manhattan Company; and that if any such draft existed purporting to be signed by me, it must be a forgery— I fear some such use has been made of my note stolen last Summer from Isaac Hull Adams— My House is turning again into a Hospital—Mary and Elizabeth Adams are both still confined to their chambers, and my wife was taken ill this Evening— Our Trunks and boxes from Boston arrived here this day.
18. V. Friday.

Mary was this day so far recovered that she was able to come below to breakfast and dinner; but Elizabeth is still confined, and my wife kept her bed all day yesterday and until this Evening, when we made in her bed-chamber a partie quarrée at whist— Giusta was here this morning and had been yesterday to Alexandria, but found nothing there of what he had anticipated— He told me that Dr Lovell’s house had been struck off to Gadsby for 7800. dollars which is a fair price for it. I called again at the Franklin Insurance Office and found Mr Bradley there—but Mr Grammer was not, nor had he signed my certificate. Mr Bradley said he had spoken to him of my proposal to declare an extra dividend, and to call for a second instalment of five dollars upon each share, and that he approved it. But suggested another plan; to double the capital, by calling for another instalment, and giving notes for four times the amount of that instalment; there by making the whole capital 250000 dollars, and the sum paid in 20 per Cent of that amount— My objection to that is, that instead of reducing it doubles the amount of the contingent notes.— I called at the Intelligencer Office, and looked over the election returns in the Boston Newspapers of Tuesday and Wednesday last— The election was held on Monday; for Governor, Lieutenant Governor, Senators and Representatives, for the State Legislature, and for an electoral ticket for the election of a President and Vice President of the United States; and for members of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 25th. Congress— The returns are marked by some extraordinary peculiarities. The whigs as they now call themselves have succeeded in Boston, by a majority of about 2000. and will have throughout the State a majority of about ten thousand but the Antimasons who all voted last year for Edward Everett as Governor, have this year divided, and the larger part of them voted for Morton. This is counterbalanced by a great increase of the whig party vote— In the ninth District Hastings has carried the Election against Alexander H. Everett by a majority of more than six hundred votes; but in theParmenter has carried it against Hoare— In the 24 Towns of my own District, the returns shew a small majority for Morton as Governor, and for the Van Buren electoral ticket But there are published returns from only two towns, of the votes for member of Congress— Abington, where the
vote stated is of 252. for me, and 6 scattering; and Rochester, where it is 140 for me, and 222 for J. Thomas of Plymouth— In all the whig Papers there is no more notice of the election to Congress for the 12th. District, than if no such election had taken place— I was nominated by an Antimasonic Meeting— The whigs, and the democrats, had meetings for the other elections, but made no nomination of me, or of any other person— Whether the movement in Rochester was in concert with other Towns, does not yet appear— I received this morning a Letter from Chancellor Kent concerning the Dissertations on the Congress of Nations, and an answer from the acting Secretary of War, to the pension claims of Thomas Vinson. Still unfavourable
19. IV:15. Saturday.

I finished this morning the alphabetical arrangement of the index to my volume of Letters, and shall now have more leisure for my Diary and correspondence— I was on my way to visit judge Cranch when I met him coming to my house— He turned back, and I went with him to his where I saw Mrs Cranch, and her daughter Mrs Rufus Dawes.— I stopped at the Franklin Insurance Office, but there was no person there— Then at the Intelligencer Office, where I saw Mr Gales—he gave me some Boston Newspapers, containing further election returns from Massachusetts, but none for the member of Congress from the 12th. District— In the 10th the whigs nominated N. B. Borden, but many of them voted for William Baylies. I called also at Gowen and Jacobs’s, and ordered a Cask of Claret wine, having already received one of White Sicily— I met in the Street Commodore Patterson with N. Amory. He had just been to visit me— My wife and Mary appear to be recovering; but Elizabeth suffers with her cough severely, and cannot leave her chamber.— I received yesterday a Letter from J. Cutts Smith of the daily Times Office, at Boston, with a Petition to Congress signed by 1100 names, praying for the removal of the duties upon foreign Coal— Mr Smith in his Letter says he believes it is the intention, but says not of whom; to forward one to Mr Webster, and one or more to Mr Lawrence; but he gives no intimation why this one is sent to me; and I know not the man who sends it— The Article of Coal is a very advantageous one for leading to a general onset upon the Tariff compromise.
20. V. Sunday.

At the Presbyterian Church and at Morning service I heard Mr Fowler from 2. Timothy 3.7. “Ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth”— The Epistles to Timothy are Letters of Instructions from Paul his teacher, to him as a Minister of the Gospel— The text of this morning is part of an admonition to the disciple to avoid communication, and especially controversy with a certain class of persons, having the form of godliness, and professing to be Christians, but grossly vicious and immoral, inculcating false and pernicious doctrines, yet with plausible manners, creeping into houses, deceived themselves and deceiving others—perverting silly women, of such as are ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth— Such a class of persons he warns him will arise in the last days,—by which he must have meant some time during the life and Ministry of Timothy, whom he charges to avoid them— It is evident indeed from the context that this class of persons had arisen already and that they were mischievously perverting both the Christian Doctrines, and the morals of the
Christians— He reminds Timothy, that his gospel consists in preaching the Resurrection of Christ from the dead; and he specifies as one of the heresies already held forth by false Doctors was that the Resurrection had already past— It is not very clear what this opinion was; but it seems by implication to deny a future resurrection, and thereby to unsettle the essential part of the gospel preached by Paul; namely that the resurrection of Christ from the dead was the demonstration of the immortality of the Soul; and that as he had risen, so all his disciples should rise from the dead— The Class of Persons however described by St. Paul in this text and context did not originate after the writing of his Epistle, nor have they been extinguished to this day— They have formed and still form a part of the family of man— Vicious morals, beclouded intellects, plausible and fallacious doctrines, combining to creep into houses and seduce silly woman, ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth, belong to all the ages of Christianity, and the text is drawn deep from the nature of man, rather than from any thing peculiar to the age of Paul, or from the duties of Timothy— After dinner at St. Johns Church, Mr Hawley read part of the Evening Service for the 25th. Sunday after Trinity—but omitted the Psalms and the Lesson from the old Testament— He read the second Lesson, which was the 4th. chapter of the first Epistle of John, and instead of a Sermon, extemporized about five minutes of comment upon that chapter— There were about twenty persons present, one of whom was Major Macomb, who gave me the aid of his umbrella to come— It rained heavily all the afternoon and Evening none of the Ladies or children therefore could attend public worship— I was engaged in redeeming the arrears of my Diary— Dr Huntt was here.
21. IV:30. Monday.—

Redeeming arrears of Diary— Mrs Adams received a Letter from our Son, Charles at Boston, which deeply afflicts us with alarm; for the state of his wife’s health— It has been bad for nearly a year past— In the Spring he took her upon an excursion to the western part of New-York and Canada—but she returned quite unwell— She seemed to have recovered, part of the time while with us at Quincy; but before her removal to Boston, upon the first of this Month was again drooping in health, and has since been very ill— Her health and Spirits have been among the most precious enjoyments of my life; and they have been the exquisite happiness of my Son. Let me not distrust a merciful Providence by foreboding a reverse.— I called again at the Franklin Insurance Office, and found there both the President, Mr Grammer, and Mr Bradley the Secretary— I signed as Administrator on the Estate of my Son John the transfer of the thirty Shares of Stock, standing in his name, and received the new certificate for them in my own— Mr Grammer shewed me the Memorial of the President and Directors to Congress for the renewal and modification of their Charter, which expires in 1838. The memorial was presented, but not acted upon at the last Session— I approved most of the modifications of the Charter requested in the memorial, and upon conversing with Mr Grammer and Mr Bradley, became very doubtful of the practicability of my own proposal to convert the reserved fund into the permanent capital Stock of the Company— The difficulty is that by dividing it, as Stock, of the Stockholders it would cease to be a reserved fund as prescribed by the
act of incorporation—and although the amount would remain equally responsible for all the obligations of the company, the Stockholders would cease to be responsible upon their contingent notes, for one fourth of their present obligations. The security of the assured by the Policies of the company would therefore be diminished to the same amount as the contingent notes of the Stockholders would be reduced, and the reserved fund, though raised to the full extent required by the charter would be diverted from its purpose, by being made the separate property of the Stockholders— My plan is practicable only by reserving the 20000 dollars required by Law, and continuing a semi-annual reserve till it shall amount to 25000 dollars more; and that could undoubtedly be converted, by an extra dividend into permanent capital— Mr Grammer mentioned his own project of doubling the amount of capital, and of the contingent notes; but to that I have a great aversion. At the National Intelligencer Office, I saw both the partners, Gales and Seaton, but they had this day, no newspapers by the mail from Boston.
22. III and IV:30. Tuesday.

By the uncomfortable, and now to me very difficult process of writing by Lamplight morn and Evening several successive days, I have at length brought up the arrears of my Diary within reaching distance, that is three days, and now begin to write daily one or two very short answers to Letters— I walked to the Capitol and saw Mr Franklin the Clerk of the House of Representatives, but could not procure either the Documents of the last Session, or the Journals of the Senate— They have not come from the Book binders.— At the Office of the National Intelligencer I saw both the Editors, and the Newspapers containing the returns of elections in all parts of the Union— From my own District there is in the Boston Advocate of Saturday a return from the town of Weymouth in the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts, which with those from Abington and Rochester, are all that I have yet found— The District is not even named in any other Boston Newspaper, except the National Advocate— From the three returns published it would seem that in Abington, the three parties all voted for me; that in Rochester, where the whigs have a large majority, they voted for J. Thomas—and that in Weymouth, where they are in a small minority they did not vote at all.— The vote for me is only of the antimasons, and portions of the two other parties, neither of which ventured a nomination against me, but each of which was ready to support one if it had been made. This was a perilous passage through a narrow strait; and will certainly not be repeated— Mr Seaton gave me an autograph Letter from the former President James Monroe, to Tench Ringgold, written in December 1829. at Richmond, where he was then President of the Convention for amending the Constitution of the State of Virginia— Seaton asked me to send this autograph, to Mr Jared Sparks at Cambridge, who had written to him to procure one for the royal collection at Dresden— I had received just before I left Quincy a Letter from Mr Sparks containing the same request, at the suggestion of Mr George Ticknor, now travelling in Europe, and a Sojourner at Dresden— He wrote to Mr Sparks that in the royal collection of autographs there, they had there, of all the Presidents of the United States excepting Mr Monroe; a vacancy which Mr Ticknor, wished to have the means of filling up. I had delayed answering Mr Sparks’s Letter, in the expectation of finding here
an autograph of Mr Monroe addressed to me, which I could send for the Dresden collection— This Letter to Ringgold will however answer the purpose as well, and I promised to forward it to Sparks— This afternoon the Ladies all went to see Mrs Frye— I returned General Macomb’s visit, but he was not at home. We had an evening party at whist, and a visit from Mr Woodbury the Secretary of the Treasury.
23. V. Wednesday.

Morning visit from Coll. James Thomas, loquacious as ever, about his own affairs and those of the public. At the last Session of Congress he obtained an Act for the Settlement of his accounts according to the principles of equity, which in the practice of our Government is equivalent to the discretion of the accounting Officers— They accordingly take their own Time for auditing such accounts, and if they do not make them a source of profit to themselves, they make the claimant sufficiently sensible of their power— Thomas, who understands his own interest, works to obtain his Settlement by influence, and as Albion K. Parris of Maine, is now second Comptroller of the Treasury, Thomas has employed F. O. J. Smith the member from Portland, as his Agent and Attorney, to prevail upon Mr Parris to discern the equity of his accounts— This is the way of doing business in this Country at this Time— Smith is a member of Congress with political influence— Thomas employs and pays him as his Agent and Attorney— Parris, Comptroller of the Treasury, indebted perhaps to the influence of Smith for his place, has a discretionary power to admit or reject the items of Thomas’s Accounts— And all this is in the regular course of business— Thomas told me also that it was rumoured that some great fraud had been discovered in the returns of the electoral College of Pennsylvania; and that there was some question whether the Governor would issue his proclamation declaring who were the persons elected— He had much more political gossiping scarcely worthy of being recollected.— In my walk before dinner, I viewed the foundation of the new building which they are erecting for the Patent Office; on which they are employing the granite, found in Maryland, about 18 Miles distant from Baltimore, and which closely resembles the Quincy Stone— My wife, with Mary, Elizabeth and the two children spent the Evening at Mrs W. S. Smith’s— Mr Smith returned last Evening from New-York with Elizabeth De Wint— Mr Frye spent the Evening with me, and gave me a full account of his management of my business here during my absence— There is no more prudent economical or judicious manager of property in this City— Yet such are the frauds, evasions, and clamours of tenants for repairs, that my houses here instead of yielding income have brought me largely in debt— General and Mrs Macomb were here and left an invitation for the Ladies to a tea-party, for to-morrow Evening.
24.— V:30 Thursday.

The recent arrears of my diary were this morning fully redeemed, but my correspondence is irredeemable. Much of this morning was consumed in making up packets for persons who have requested copies of the Eulogy upon James Madison— I walked out about an hour before dinner, and called at the Office of the National Intelligencer— They had received no newspapers from Boston this morning— Mr Gales whom I saw, had heard the report of the errors or frauds in the returns of votes for the Electoral College in Pennsylvania but there was nothing about it in the Intelligencer of this Morning— Mr Gales informed me of the wreck last Sunday Night of the Ship Bristol, near Rockaway, Long-Island, with loss of the lives of eighty Passengers, and of a Steamboat disaster between
Louisville and Cincinnati, by which 13 persons among whom was George L. Kinnard, a member of Congress from Indiana, were so badly scalded that their recovery was desperate. Gales was somewhat comforted by his political election news from Illinois and Missouri— I called at Mr Lowrie’s house, and viewed his furniture which is to be sold at auction to-morrow— Mr Lowrie was there but not much furniture— He resigns his Office as Secretary of the Senate, and removes westward— I answered a Letter from the Secretary of State Forsyth informing me that there are upon the files of the Department a private Letter from Joel R Poinsett to me of 7. June 1827. from Mexico, where he was then Minister Plenipotentiary; and one ofAugust of the same year, from me to H. Clay then Secretary of State.— I have desired that they should be returned to me— Mary dined and spent the Evening at Mr Frye’s, and I went to the Tea-party at Genl. Macomb’s— Met there a numerous company, very few of whom were of my acquaintance— The visiting population of Washington pass through a total change about once in eight years— Congress and the Executive Government do the same.— The exceptions are very few.— General Macomb, is to leave the City at three O’Clock to-morrow Morning to attend the Court of Enquiry at Frederick.
25. VI.30. Friday.

My Time is slipping away, and I am doing nothing— I rose this morning two hours later than my regular time, because I had spent the last Evening abroad, and because the morning was so cold, that I could not write before breakfast— This is an incurable infirmity of the Winter, which has begun this Season earlier than usual— The consequence is that I must write between breakfast and dinner, a time when numberless unforeseen, and for the most part trivial calls dissipate the day till it is imperceptibly and irretrievably gone— This morning M. A. Giusta was here, consulting me, about the purchase of a dinner set of Liverpool Crockery ware; a grave concern which has absorbed several hours of time since our arrival here— The Servants break up a set, in about 2 years; and for economy’s sake we have been desirous of purchasing a set at auction— This has failed, but Giusta has negotiated with Dyer the auctioneer for a second hand, and of course incomplete set, for which I have agreed to pay 25 dollars or about half price— This was the business of the morning, till near two O’Clock, when I walked out and encountered a blustering Northwester, that I was driven back into the House, within an hour, the fingers of both my hands pinched as if with thumb-screws. We spent the Evening at whist.— I wrote a few lines to Governor Edward Everett, and to John H. Eastburn, of whom I have asked another hundred copies of the Eulogy on James Madison— This is occasioned by a number of applications which I have received, from various persons Strangers to me, and who have just curiosity enough to see the work, without being at the cost of a quarter of a dollar to pay for it— There are in the eastern central and western parts of the Country, multitudes of collectors of pamphlets of this description, who bedaub me with flattery, for gratuitous copies of my Speeches and Orations; while others do them about equal honour, by malicious and caustic reviews— There is in the Boston Courier which Gales this day sent me, such a Review of the Eulogy on Madison by a blue-light federalist of the Hartford Convention School—while in the Telegraph Newspaper of this day, there is a deadly onset upon me, from the clanking Chains of a Southern Slave-holder, for my Speech upon the Texian Imposture, last June— The idea this Evening occurred to me, of making a collection of as many of my writings which have been published in pamphlets, to have two or three sets of them, bound up in Volumes, for gifts to my grand-children— The three Eulogies may be literary and political curiosities,
in a century from this day; but of most, perhaps all my other writings, no trace will remain, unless in some such collection made by myself. I have already had two Volumes of Miscellanies chiefly of my composing, bound, and have here and at Quincy the materials for one or two Volumes more— It may be worth my while however to proceed more methodically, and to collect as far as possible, all that has been printed, of my writing— It must always be very incomplete, as there are many articles of newspapers, magazines, and Reviews, long since forgotten by myself; and much official correspondence in Public Documents, mingled with other papers, and not worthy of being selected among them— The public documents among which there are Letters and Memoirs of mine are so numerous and so various, that it would not be possible for me to indicate them all.
26. V:30. Saturday.— Fahrenheit 22. after Sunrise

Cold morning so that I could not write. I made out however a very imperfect list of my published writings, to serve as a first sketch to be hereafter enlarged, and brought into form, and I read part of two Lectures of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica, forming part of his Treatise upon language. It is a work of an extraordinary character; and deserving of much consideration at least from me— It assumes the merit of a profound discovery, undetected by all the writers upon metaphysics of former ages— There is something of the Jeremy Bentham character about it— A free use of neologies—words of the authors invention, but deficient both in euphony and precision— A style, deeply studied; affecting originality—antithetic—highly figurative, and often stranded upon the commonest rules of Grammar. He quotes Berkley, Locke, Hume, Descartes and Reid, as mere Schoolboys, utterly ignorant of his great discovery, and consequently committing egregious blunders, which it has been reserved to him to expose— But instead of quoting them in their own words, he gives his own version or paraphrase of particular passages in their writings, and then shews the absurdity of his own conceptions which he imputes to them— He has long and perseveringly and painfully meditated his subject into a system, which has unity and consistency and some ingenuity of invention— But I find it very difficult to understand him, and am doubtful whether he has really presented some new views of language, or whether his book is a mere bundle of common truisms mystified into an appearance of metaphysical refinement— Giusta was here with a bill of the Crockery ware which he purchased for me yesterday: Dr. Huntt who is going to Harper’s ferry, and beyond, to Mr Outerbrige Horsey’s— Mr Blanchard the miniature painter who somedays since brought me a Letter of recommendation from A. H. Everett, was here again to-day and shewed me a handsome miniature which he has painted, of his own wife— But he finds nothing to do here, and I have compassion for his forlorn condition— He talks of going to Europe next Spring, but wil not have the means— Mr Richard Cuttis was here too and borrowed two old Catalogues of harvard College, where he wished to look up some of the survivors of his old College acquaintance— The children dined at Mr Frye’s— After dinner I walked an hour till after Sunset— Cold as January still— Evening party at whist— I despatched the Letters to Governor Everett and to Eastburn, and several copies of the Eulogy.
27. VI.30. Sunday— Fahrenheit 24

Morning service at the Presbyterian Church. Elizabeth C. Adams and Mary Louisa went with me and heard Mr Fowler from John 5.40. “And ye will not come to me, that ye might have life.”— This was a thorough-going Calvinistic declamation, charging the whole auditory and indeed almost all christendom with this stubborn wilful refusal to go to Christ, or to submit to his Laws, to enjoy eternal Life— The reproach which Christ in the text applies to a few of the Jews of his own time, the preacher cast upon the whole mass of Christians of the present age— It is not to be denied that there are great multitudes of nominal Christians in the present age who refuse to go to Christ; but they are not generally such as frequent any Christian Church— For myself, I repel the charge, and do not believe it true, of most of those to whom it is addressed— I liked this Sermon as little as any one that I have heard for several years.— Mrs Adams and Mary with her daughter Georgiana, went to St. John’s Church— Thomas J. Frye dined with us— After dinner I went with Elizabeth and Mary Louisa to St. John’s— Mr Hawley read the Evening Service for Advent Sunday and gave a short Sermon from Genesis 6.5. [“]And God saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every imagination of the thoughts of his heart, was only evil continually.”— This is also a favourite text for Calvinistic commentary; but the ruggedness of Mr Hawley’s Calvinism, has very much smoothed down— On returning home from Church I found Mrs W. S. Smith here; but she soon returned. I answered a Letter received last Summer from Richard Henry Lee; to send with it a copy of my Eulogy on Mr Madison— Evening in conversation with the Ladies.
28. VI:30. Monday— Fahrenheit 32. Snow.

The frosty morning, delayed my rising two hours after the property time, and then denying me use of the pen, compelled me to read two or three Lectures of Alexander B. Johnson’s Treatise on Language, or the relations of words to things— He thinks there is a great and very pernicious delusion upon this subject. prevailing throughout the world; and especially among all the writers upon language and upon metaphysicks hitherto.— He is convinced that this is a great and wonderful discovery of his own— He very studiously avoids the use of the word idea, and assumes that there are only six classes of thoughts one for each of the five Senses, and one of what he calls verbal thoughts having relation to words, and not to things. The mistake which he supposes all mankind to have made, and which he only has detected, consists in holding words to be the representations of things, while in reality things are the representatives of words, and he stoutly maintains that nothing exists that is not perceptible to the human senses— Whether he is aware of the consequences of his own argument is something doubtful— His system if it means any thing is materialism— He limits for example the divisibility of matter to the perception of it by the sense and considers all words indicative of existence not perceptible to one of the five senses, as representatives without a constituent—words without meaning.— He puzzles himself much; and puzzles me not a little— The great part of his book seems to be very trivial truth worked up into mystery, and the rest metaphysical skirmishing in search of unintelligible axioms.— Perhaps what I deem defect in the work is my own—
Mr Ferdinand Peddrich is a German Sculptor; born at Dresden in November 1798— He came with Dr Todsen, and brought me a Letter of Recommendation from Mrs S. Harrison Smith who had mentioned him to me the other Evening at General Macomb’s— He had also a recommendatory certificate from the Sculptor Thorwaldsen at Rome, whose pupil he had been—and he had the diploma from the Pope, and the ribband and cross of the golden spur— He wants employment in his profession by Congress, and solicits my influence— He has executed several pieces of Sculpture, which I promised to go and see at Georgetown next Thursday— Dr. Sewall also paid me a morning visit—and told me that Mrs Katherine Brown had for several years past resided with him— I walked round the Capitol before dinner, and we made a party at whist in the Evening— There was a light fall of Snow—merely to powder the ground—
29. VI:30. Tuesday.

Digging deeper into the Treatise of Mr Alexander B. Johnson upon language, without understanding it any better. As I proceed it appears to me that Mr Johnson either has no distinct idea of what he himself means by the word language or that he views it in a partial, and indefinite light.— The great property of language is to be an instrument for the communication of thought— Words are the elements of language; but they must be carefully distinguished from the idea which they represent from property to which they refer, and for the form in which they are used.— A word spoken is an articulate sound, conveying an idea from one mind to another of men both speaking the same language— A word written is a picture of the same articulate sound conveying through the eye to the mind the same idea as is conveyed by the Articulate sound through the ear— The word has wings—it flies from the mouth of the Speaker to the ear of the hearer— Written or printed it flies from the paper to the reader; but no man in his senses takes it either for the object which it represents, or for the sensation of the Speaker or writer— Mr Johnson seems to think that all mankind are constantly making one or the other of those mistakes— The young man from the Office of the Clerk of the House of Representatives brought me some paper, and Mr M’Cormick the Postmaster at the Post-Office of the House sent me some other Stationery— I walked round the Capitol before dinner, and journalized in the Evening— Elizabeth De Wint dined and spent the Evening here, and we had a party at whist—
30— VI:30. Wednesday.

I met Russel Freeman yesterday in my walk— He has come on here again from Sandwich to make interest for an Office—to recover that which was taken from him of Collector at New Bedford or some other— Any other that will give him a comfortable subsistence— He told me that he had seen Mr Woodbury the Secretary of the Treasury this morning; and that his discourse was encouraging— He shewed me also a Letter from Mr Woodbury to him written last May, and which was flattering to his hopes— He says that Lemuel Williams the present Collector of New-Bedford has made one of these land jobbing fortunes, and does not expect to be reappointed, at the expiration of his present term which has about one year more to run.
That he neither needs nor wants the office, and might as well be dismissed from it at once— I told him he must not expect that— And must be satisfied, if he can be restored to his Office when Williams’s term shall expire— He said he could live until that time— That he had about 3000 dollars, which would last him for a year; and that his motto instead, of the trivial one dum spiro spero, was with the words inverted—dum spero spiro— He enquired, if I had seen the returns of the Congressional Election for the 12th. District of Massachusetts— I said I had the returns from the Towns in Plymouth County; and mentioned the peculiarity of the returns from Rochester, Wareham and Plymouth. He said that the votes in Rochester and Wareham, were given by the influence of Charles J. Holmes, a cunning man without principle; a factory agent of Barnabas Hedge who procures votes for John Thomas of Plymouth, because Thomas married a daughter of Hedge— Charles J. Holmes is the member from the old Colony on the available ticket of Electors of President and Vice-President— As to the small number of votes given in Plymouth, he said the Hedge party not daring to vote for Thomas would not vote at all—and Schuyler Sampson was not inclined to give a large vote of the Van-Buren party, on the Henshaw policy of keeping the party itself as small as possible— I received a Letter from Schuyler Sampson himself containing a draft on the Bank of the Metropolis, for which I obtained a draught on the Commonwealth’s Bank at Boston, which by endorsement I made payable to his order, and forwarded to him. I received also a Letter from Thomas L. M’Kenney, at Philadelphia; with an enclosure for Gales and Seaton—enquiring for a report of a Talk between the Winebago chiefs and me in 1828. I took this note to the Office of the National Intelligencer, and saw Mr Gales— There is notice in the paper that they will publish my Eulogy upon James Madison entire.— I asked Mr Gales to send me the proof slips, for revisal, to correct some errors of the press, which he accordingly promised.— We had a whist party this Evening.

Day. My inability to write in the morning, for want of a warm room, changes the character of my occupations— I now rise between six and seven—two hours later than my proper time and read till Breakfast—first an hour upon Mr Johnson’s treatise on language—then an hour with my two Granddaughters in the Apocrypha, and in the New Testament— After breakfast, the Newspapers, daily Letters, and unforeseen trifles of business, swallow up the time till one or two—then a walk of one or two hours; followed soon after my return by dinner between 3 and 4. leaves scarcely a remnant of after dinner daylight till the Sunset comes; then the evening twilight and then darkness— Meantime the diary of the preceding day is in abeyance; or must be written by scraps, morning noon or evening— My correspondence equally flags— The Session of Congress is now close at hand— My leisure of four weeks in which I hoped to do much has melted away, and I have done nothing; nor have I now a hope of any thing more or better— I must drift with the tide.
